projects.title: IBM Cloud Infrastructure RCA Process
projects.description: When I started at IBM, the cloud infrastructure was largely composed from the SoftLayer acquisition, which had only happened three years previous. Shortly after I arrived, IBM Cloud selected to migrate to ServiceNow for customer tickets, Incident Response, and RCA work. First the software dev teams moved over and as they moved, the Cloud Servicenow instance was customized for how SOFTWARE dev teams manage devops.  When I was given the task to develop a customer facing process for RCAs, I realized I first had to help migrate IBM Cloud Infrastructure to ServiceNow. This meant I had to work with the product owners and explain the unique requirements of INFRASTRUCTURE teams when managing incident response and RCAs.Then I had to work with the ServiceNow developers to update incident forms, ticket forms, etc. to include things like Datacenter name and location, Hardware makes and models, collaboration pathways between Network, Platform, and Development teams. Once I helped integrate and test these new customization's, I was asked to help train the Infrastructure teams on how to use Cloud ServiceNow for incident management. This was not an easy task, but the transition was accomplished successfully.

projects.title: IBM Cloud 'Customer Incident Response' Process
projects.description: After successfully moving IBM Cloud Infrastructure over to ServiceNow, I was asked to design a process for customers who were impacted by an outage, to request a copy of the RCA.¬† I examined the RCA process we were running in ServiceNow and found it to not be customer consumable. I also found some gaps in how the process was being run. Since management wanted RCA information available to all impacted customers, I had to address these gaps.¬†  Infrastructure teams were using both ServiceNow and the old SoftLayer system, as it had more tools for working with DataCenters, Servers, Power Management, etc. This system unfortunately had conflicting time information and other issues. This lead to conflicts on identification of the root cause. A DevOps team who experienced an issue will have a different view of the incident than the network or database teams.  I updated the RCA process to include the 'Five Whys' of root cause determination. This proved difficult for teams to exercise in practice. I developed and taught all infrastructure teams on the new RCA process and included an detailed walk-through of the Five Whys.¬†  Finally, I developed a new document called the 'Customer Incident Response' document that provided a customer accessible version of the internal RCA. This included removing any restricted information. Also, the language was updated to be less technical and more easily understood. In this document, we explained the event details, identified the root cause, and the specific actions that would be taken to ensure this kind of event did not reoccur.  I had additional functionality implemented in ServiceNow, so customers could check a box in a support ticket and it would kick off this now fairly automated process.

projects.title: IBM SOS Watson X Challenge
projects.description: Since I'm all about process improvement, I decided to use the WatsonX challenge for employees to create something useful to my team.   We have git pages with instructions for our internal customers, but they are managed by several people and it can sometimes be difficult to navigate.   I cloned the gitpage repo hosting these customer pages, then embedded a Watson Assistant agent. I programmed the assistant with some commonly asked questions our team receives, and linked to the best pages to find the requested information.   While this was basically a tech-demo, the results were positive and the benefit to customers was obvious. Watson Assistant understood variations of the questions, and summarized the correct information to customers, while directing them to the correct web-pages for further information.   Further research and testing showed that I could use 'LM Studio' to host a local LLM, link that to 'Anything LLM' where I could import all our data from the Git-pages. Then the Natural Language abilities would greatly improve, and the AI would search all documents, and compile a more through response with links. This became my next skunkworks (unofficial) project.

projects.title: IBM SOS Change Management
projects.description: Shortly after moving from Cloud to Security Operational Services (SOS), I was asked to look at the change control process. Some process documentation existed, but was in need of updating.   I updated the process, connecting 'Change Requests' made in GitHub to the updated process. Additionally, these change requests were reviewed by a 'Change Acceptance' board (CAB), but there were some gaps.   - I updated the CAB review process to:    - Require a deadline for the weekly call so Architects could have time to review CR and be ready for CAB    - Require a quorum for review and approval    - Updated the CR template with a better process flow that included labels for internal approval, CAB request, and CAB approval.   I ran the weekly CAB calls, notifying reviews via Slack in advance of any reviews, to give them time to prepare. I recorded the calls for additional audit evidence, and approved all CR that passed the CAB.   These changes greatly improved the operation of change management in my new organization.

projects.title: IBM SOS Customer Project Management
projects.description: After I started in Security Operational Services (SOS), we began organizing customer more into Business Units (BU), rather than individual teams. This proved beneficial to specifically address the business drivers, risks, timelines, and outcomes for these organizations.   I was given the CIO office as my internal customer. I served as the SOS Project Manager for CIO. Here is a small subset of my work:  - Managed the on-boarding of IBM internal teams to the Security Operations Center (SOC). Conducted weekly calls with the CIO Business Information Security Officer (BISO) to make sure SOS was addressing any security concerns and that the associated security projects were progressing. - Managed a project to improve scanning by implementing a new scanner design/deployment. This included developing a 'Responsibility Assignment Matrix' (RACI) to document roles and responsibilities. Also lead calls to identify issues and worked collaborativley with disperate teams to mitigate. - Managed a project to assist CIO's network engineering with implementing an process for authenticating devices requesting network access, and assigning them to the correct VLANS. This process interacted with our SOS database, which was the 'source of truth' document for registered devices.  - Managed a project to deploy Distributed Log Collectors (DLC) for CIO to communicate with the SOS SIEM and send revelant logs for monitoring by the Security Operations Center (SOC)

projects.title: IBM SOS Proof of Concept for Localized AI integration
projects.description: Using the outcome of my WatsonX Challenge (see other accomplishment), I wanted to build a 'proof of concept. Due to data security regulations (and no budget), I had to use use free open source AI solutions.  The initial POC was to help our team interact with customer account data more efficiently.¬†  1. I installed 'SQL server' and 'MySQLWorkbench' on my laptop and imported our customer account data.¬†  2. I installed LM studio and downloaded an IBM LLM for testing.¬†  3. I installed Anywhere LLM and imported our customer facing documentation.¬†  4. I installed 'Anaconda' to run programs in an isolated environment. I installed tools like 'Visual Studio Code', 'Juypter Lab', and others.¬†  Once initial configuration was done, I was able to make queries about customer documentation in Anywhere LLM, and have it use the IBM LLM in LM Studio to understand and answer the natural language question.¬†  The next step was to connect to the SQL database and ask natural language questions about these data. Unfortunately this POC was interrupted by the need to look for another work opportunity, so I've moved this idea over to my personal systems and am improving on the concept by running n8n in a docker container. I'll post about this in a blog update.

projects.title: Multicloud Lab with Terraform and Ansible
projects.description: Excited to share my latest cloud lab project on GitHub!  I‚Äôve built and automated a multi-cloud environment using Terraform to provision an AWS EC2 instance and an IBM Virtual Server Instance (VSI), then configured them with Ansible to install Python 3.10 and pip for AI workloads. This hands-on setup tackled real-world challenges like SSH key management, security group tweaks, and pip installation quirks.   Check out the repo here: https://github.com/Cloud-Ops-Dev/cloud-lab-terraform-ansible  Highlights: VPC/subnet setup, floating IP management, and a polished README with screenshots. Lessons: Region consistency, secure API handling, and automating with precision.  Next up, looking at IBM Watson automation with Cisco/Juniper network simulations to blend AI with networking‚Äîstay tuned!
